item.title: Pakistani Military Bombs Militant Hide-Outs
item.description: After fighter jets pounded militant targets in North Waziristan, the military announced that it had launched a “comprehensive operation” against militants in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Netanyahu Blames Hamas in Kidnapping of Israeli Youths
item.description: The remarks Sunday by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel followed the arrests overnight of 80 people, most of them Hamas activists, and the closing of parts of the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers searched for three teenagers Sunday in the southern West Bank city of Hebron.

item.title: Bombings Kill Up to 21 People in Baghdad
item.description: Two attacks that rattled central Baghdad were the first major bombings there since Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Militants Claim Mass Execution of Iraqi Soldiers
item.description: Insurgents from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria boasted on Twitter that they had executed 1,700 people, posting gruesome photos to support their claim.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: After Coup, Foreign Workers Stream Out of Thailand
item.description: In a chaotic exodus, tens of thousands of Cambodians have left the country, apparently driven by fears of a crackdown on illegal laborers by the military junta.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Rift Bared as Palestinians Aid Israel in Search for Teenagers Missing in West Bank
item.description: The crisis underscored the complexity of Israel’s relations with the Palestinian Authority and the authority’s deep differences with Hamas despite a recent reconciliation pact.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Worry Under the Big Top as Mexico City Moves to Ban Circus Animals
item.description: After Mexico City’s legislative assembly approved a ban on circus animals, the country’s tight-knit community of family-owned circuses is on the defensive.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Rebels’ Fast Strike in Iraq Was Years in the Making
item.description: The group’s sweep into Mosul and farther south appeared to catch many Iraqi and U.S. officials by surprise, but the gains were the realization of a yearslong strategy of state-building.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, KAREEM FAHIM and BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cars carrying people who fled Mosul lined up at a checkpoint on the road to Erbil in northern Iraq on Saturday.

item.title: News: Latest Updates on the Insurgency in Iraq
item.description: Follow the latest developments in Iraq on Saturday, as the government in Baghdad attempts to regroup following a string of victories by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Memo From Moscow: After Annexing Crimea, Euphoric Russia Turns Thoughts to Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine continues to dominate public discourse in Russia, and nothing else — not housing concerns, political issues or even an indoor smoking ban — really competes.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artemy Lebedev, a prominent, outspoken designer, expressed pride over the Crimea annexation.

item.title: Frank Schirrmacher, German Newspaper Publisher, Dies at 54
item.description: Mr. Schirrmacher was co-publisher of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, one of Germany’s most respected publications.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Cambodian Activist’s Fall Exposes Broad Deception
item.description: Activists say the story of Somaly Mam is part of a larger tale of deception meant to attract foreign money into impoverished Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Somaly Mam left the foundation bearing her name after questions arose about her history.

item.title: Korea’s Fish Special: A Delicate Mix of Outhouse and Ammonia
item.description: Served most often as chewy pink slabs of sashimi, hongeo, or fermented skate, is prized in South Korea for fumes so strong they sometimes cause people’s mouths to peel.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Palace of Squatters Is a Symbol of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The overcrowding of Salaam Palace is a crisis within a larger, nationwide emergency set off by a fresh surge of more than 50,000 migrants to Italy since the beginning of the year.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants from the African nation of Eritrea in a refugee camp close to a railway station in Rome. Italy is reeling from a surge of more than 50,000 migrants so far this year.

item.title: Separatists Down Military Transport Jet, Killing 49 in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The attack was the deadliest episode for the Ukrainian military since the unrest began in the country’s east.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: An armed pro-Russian separatist gathered ammunition at the site of the crash in Luhansk on Saturday.

item.title: Brazilian Prisoners Manufacture Soccer Balls
item.description: Dozens of inmates manufacture soccer balls at a Brazilian prison near one of the 12 cities hosting the World Cup games.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An inmate cleaning a soccer ball ready for shipment from the Nelson Hungria Penitentiary in Contagem, Brazil, where a prison factory produces 400 balls a day.

item.title: Officials Fear Moner Mohammad Abusalha’s Jihad Video Will Inspire Others
item.description: American officials believe a recruitment video circulating in extremist circles shows the American who killed dozens in a recent attack, and they are concerned that others will follow in his path.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Moner Mohammad Abusalha, left, is thought to be the man appearing in a video meant to recruit Americans to extremism.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: 5 Principles for Iraq
item.description: There are many questions that need answering before the U.S. considers intervening.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Opinion: Chelsea Manning on the U.S. Military and Media Freedom
item.description: I saw firsthand how the United States military rationed what the American public knew about its operations in Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHELSEA MANNING
item.media:description: A supporter of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki protested in Baghdad on March 26, 2010, with a poster depicting inked fingers being hanged and alleging voter fraud in Iraq’s general election.

item.title: The Diverse Heritage of the San Antonio Spurs’ Patty Mills
item.description: Patty Mills of the San Antonio Spurs flies three flags: of Australia, the Aboriginals and the Torres Strait Islands, and like many Australians he continues to wrestle with complex questions of culture and heritage.
item.dc:creator: By BILLY WITZ
item.media:description: Patty Mills, above at center, San Antonio’s reserve point guard, is the first indigenous Australian to play in the N.B.A. finals.

item.title: Beleaguered Iraqis Court Iranian Mastermind of the Shiites Who Fought the U.S.
item.description: Iraq may see the possibility of significant aid from Iran as a means of pressuring the United States to come to Iraq’s defense with aid of its own.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Changing Maps in the Mideast
item.description: The facts on the ground are shredding the official maps of Iraq and the region.
item.dc:creator: By ROSS DOUTHAT

item.title: Afghans, Looking Ahead to U.S. Withdrawal, Vote With Guarded Optimism
item.description: As voters chose Saturday between an ex-finance minister and an opposition politician, the Taliban appeared not to have launched any major attacks, at least in urban areas.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan women lined up to vote at a polling station in Herat on Saturday.

item.title: Iraq Rebels Stall North of Baghdad as Residents Brace for a Siege
item.description: An insurgent juggernaut that captured Iraq’s second-largest city and raced nearly 200 miles south in three days stalled on Saturday, leaving residents in Baghdad bracing for a siege that so far has not happened.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Thousands of volunteers have joined the Iraqi Army to combat the predominantly Sunni militants after Iraq’s most senior Shiite cleric urged followers to take up arms.

item.title: From Untended Farmland, Reserve Tries to Recreate Wilderness From Long Ago
item.description: A reserve in western Spain is at the forefront of Europe’s “rewilding” effort, which seeks to restore species and ecosystems that vanished centuries ago.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned farm near La Alamedilla. Rewilders say introducing wildlife, especially large herbivores, will prevent the land from becoming overgrown, which could hurt biodiversity.
